  <entry>
    <title>Testing the Privacy Sandbox ads relevance and measurement APIs</title>
    <link href="https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/privacy-sandbox-unified-origin-trial/" />
    <updated>2022-03-31T00:00:00+00:00</updated>
    <id>https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/privacy-sandbox-unified-origin-trial/</id>
    
      
      
      <author>
        <name>Rowan Merewood</name>
      </author>
      
    
    <content type="html"><p>The <a href="https://privacysandbox.com/open-web/">Privacy Sandbox</a> includes a selection
of proposals to enable advertising use cases without the need for cross-site
tracking. <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/origin-trials/">Origin trials</a> provide the opportunity for
developers to evaluate and provide feedback on new web technologies through
real-world testing. In previous origin trials sites have been able to test
against individual APIs. For the Topics, FLEDGE and Attribution Reporting APIs
we are providing a <strong>single origin trial</strong> that will allow sites to run unified
experiments across the APIs making up an initial version of the end-to-end ad
lifecycle. The APIs are available for <strong>local developer testing</strong> in the
<strong>Chrome 102 <a href="https://www.google.com/chrome/canary/">Canary</a></strong> release now and
we expect to make the <strong>origin trial</strong> available as soon as possible during the
<strong>Chrome 101 <a href="https://www.google.com/chrome/beta/">Beta</a></strong> window. The <a href="https://blog.chromium.org/2022/03/what-to-expect-from-ps-testing.html">Chrome
101 Beta will also see updates to the user
controls</a>
as we continue to iterate on configuration options.</p>
<p>As a developer you will be able to sign up for this single origin trial that
will allow you to test across the Topics, FLEDGE, and Attribution Reporting
APIs. This guide takes you through the configuration steps to access the APIs,
explains how to validate your configuration, and provides further resources for
testing against the APIs.</p>
<h2 id="whats-in-the-origin-trial" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#whats-in-the-origin-trial" aria-hidden="true">#</a> What's in the origin trial?</h2>
<p>The aim of this origin trial is to allow for meaningful testing across the ad
lifecycle over multiple sites. To cover this journey, the origin trial includes:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/topics/">Topics</a></strong> to observe and access a
browser's topics via <code>document.browsingTopics()</code>.</li>
<li><strong><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/fledge/">FLEDGE</a></strong> to manage a browser's interest
groups, along with ad bidding and selection based on those groups and other
signals.
<ul>
<li>In this origin trial, FLEDGE is available on desktop and includes a
specific subset of all the proposed functionality. See the <a href="https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/blob/main/Proposed_First_FLEDGE_OT_Details.md">FLEDGE
origin trial
details</a>
for more information.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><strong><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/attribution-reporting/">Attribution Reporting</a></strong> to
measure and report on the performance over the ad lifecycle.
<ul>
<li>As part of Attribution Reporting, aggregatable reports must be processed
and aggregated by an <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/attribution-reporting/summary-reports/#aggregation-service">aggregation
service</a>
to produce summary reports. We will publish additional tools and guides
for local and origin trial testing soon.</li>
<li>If you have participated in previous origin trials for Attribution
Reporting, be aware that you will need to update inline with the latest
API changes. See the <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1NY7SScCYcPc9v5wtf_fVAikFxGQTAFvwldhExN1P03Y/edit#">Migration
guide</a>
for details.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p>While this setup allows for unified testing across all these APIs, you can pick
and choose which aspects to implement—as much or as little as fits your needs.</p>
<h2 id="how-do-developers-sign-up-for-the-origin-trial" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#how-do-developers-sign-up-for-the-origin-trial" aria-hidden="true">#</a> How do developers sign up for the origin trial?</h2>
<p>All active origin trials are available at the <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/origintrials/">Chrome Origin Trials
site</a>. You will be able to register for the <strong>&quot;Privacy Sandbox
Ads APIs&quot;</strong> origin trial from here when it is available.</p>
<p>Much of the functionality available in the origin trial is intended for use in
cross-site contexts, as in when you are providing a service as a third-party on
the top-level site. To enable your origin trial for these additional contexts,
<strong>ensure that you select the option for &quot;Third-party matching&quot;</strong>.</p>
<p>You will receive an origin trial token that must be included either in a:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>&lt;meta&gt;</code> tag in the top-level page's <code>&lt;head&gt;</code> section:
<ul>
<li><code>&lt;meta http-equiv=&quot;origin-trial&quot; content=&quot;TOKEN_GOES_HERE&quot;&gt;</code></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>HTTP header in the top-level page response:
<ul>
<li><code>Origin-Trial: TOKEN_GOES_HERE</code></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p>If you are enabling the origin trial as a third-party, then you <strong>must inject
the <code>&lt;meta&gt;</code> tag</strong> into the <strong>top-level page</strong> (i.e. the first-party page, not
your own content) from your script. For example:</p>
<pre class="language-javascript"><code class="language-javascript"><span class="token keyword">const</span> otMeta <span class="token operator">=</span> document<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">createElement</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'meta'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>otMeta<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">setAttribute</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'http-equiv'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'origin-trial'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>otMeta<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">setAttribute</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'content'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token string">'TOKEN_GOES_HERE'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>document<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">querySelector</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'head'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">appendChild</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>otMeta<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span></code></pre>
<p>Learn more in <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/origin-trials/">the guide to getting started with Chrome's origin
trials</a>.</p>
<h2 id="local-testing" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#local-testing" aria-hidden="true">#</a> How do developers test locally?</h2>
<p>The individual developer pages for
<a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/topics-experiment/">Topics</a>,
<a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/fledge-experiment/">FLEDGE</a>, and <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/attribution-reporting-experiment/">Attribution
Reporting</a> provide
specific guidance on local developer testing for each API. The APIs are not on
by default and must be <a href="https://www.chromium.org/developers/how-tos/run-chromium-with-flags/">enabled via
flags</a> for
testing.</p>
<p>To enable APIs for testing, you must:</p>
<ul>
<li>be using <strong>Chrome 102 <a href="https://www.google.com/chrome/canary/">Canary</a> or
above</strong>.
<ul>
<li>FLEDGE requires desktop Chrome.</li>
<li>APIs are not available on iOS versions of Chrome.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><strong>enable the APIs</strong> using the <code>chrome://flags/#privacy-sandbox-ads-apis</code>
flag.
<ul>
<li>This flag forces the APIs on for easier testing, if you want to
replicate an eligible origin trial user where their additional settings
can still disable the APIs, then you should launch Chrome using the CLI
flags:
<code>--enable-features=BrowsingTopics,InterestGroupStorage,AllowURNsInIframes,PrivacySandboxAdsAPIs</code>.</li>
<li>Individual APIs may have more additional flags for more fine-grained
configuration, check the individual guides for details.</li>
<li>Additional flags may conflict with this one, so consider only setting
this one flag if you encounter issues.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>have the <strong>Privacy Sandbox trials enabled</strong> via Settings → Security and
privacy → Privacy Sandbox, also accessible via
<code>chrome://settings/privacySandbox</code>.</li>
<li>have <strong>third-party cookies enabled</strong> via Settings → Security and privacy →
Cookies and other site data set to either &quot;Allow all cookies&quot; or &quot;Block
third-party cookies in incognito&quot;, also accessible via
<code>chrome://settings/cookies</code>.</li>
<li>be in a standard browsing session and <strong>not Incognito mode</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="how-do-developers-check-if-the-origin-trial-is-configured-correctly" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#how-do-developers-check-if-the-origin-trial-is-configured-correctly" aria-hidden="true">#</a> How do developers check if the origin trial is configured correctly?</h2>
<p><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/origin-trial-troubleshooting/">Troubleshooting Chrome's origin trials</a>
provides a detailed checklist to validate your configuration of the origin
trial.</p>
<img alt="DevTools showing origin trial status under Applications → Frames" decoding="async" height="326" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 800px) 800px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/VWw0b3pM7jdugTkwI6Y81n6f5Yc2/GQv4Ybw6AVXCMwbyZtmN.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/VWw0b3pM7jdugTkwI6Y81n6f5Yc2/GQv4Ybw6AVXCMwbyZtmN.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VWw0b3pM7jdugTkwI6Y81n6f5Yc2/GQv4Ybw6AVXCMwbyZtmN.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VWw0b3pM7jdugTkwI6Y81n6f5Yc2/GQv4Ybw6AVXCMwbyZtmN.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VWw0b3pM7jdugTkwI6Y81n6f5Yc2/GQv4Ybw6AVXCMwbyZtmN.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VWw0b3pM7jdugTkwI6Y81n6f5Yc2/GQv4Ybw6AVXCMwbyZtmN.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VWw0b3pM7jdugTkwI6Y81n6f5Yc2/GQv4Ybw6AVXCMwbyZtmN.png?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VWw0b3pM7jdugTkwI6Y81n6f5Yc2/GQv4Ybw6AVXCMwbyZtmN.png?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VWw0b3pM7jdugTkwI6Y81n6f5Yc2/GQv4Ybw6AVXCMwbyZtmN.png?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VWw0b3pM7jdugTkwI6Y81n6f5Yc2/GQv4Ybw6AVXCMwbyZtmN.png?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VWw0b3pM7jdugTkwI6Y81n6f5Yc2/GQv4Ybw6AVXCMwbyZtmN.png?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VWw0b3pM7jdugTkwI6Y81n6f5Yc2/GQv4Ybw6AVXCMwbyZtmN.png?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VWw0b3pM7jdugTkwI6Y81n6f5Yc2/GQv4Ybw6AVXCMwbyZtmN.png?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VWw0b3pM7jdugTkwI6Y81n6f5Yc2/GQv4Ybw6AVXCMwbyZtmN.png?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VWw0b3pM7jdugTkwI6Y81n6f5Yc2/GQv4Ybw6AVXCMwbyZtmN.png?auto=format&w=1098 1098w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VWw0b3pM7jdugTkwI6Y81n6f5Yc2/GQv4Ybw6AVXCMwbyZtmN.png?auto=format&w=1252 1252w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VWw0b3pM7jdugTkwI6Y81n6f5Yc2/GQv4Ybw6AVXCMwbyZtmN.png?auto=format&w=1428 1428w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VWw0b3pM7jdugTkwI6Y81n6f5Yc2/GQv4Ybw6AVXCMwbyZtmN.png?auto=format&w=1600 1600w" width="800">
<p>DevTools shows the status for an origin trial in the Applications tab under
Frames.</p>
<p>While the origin trial will only show as active to <a href="#eligible-users">eligible
users</a> as detailed below, you can also use the <a href="#local-testing">developer
flags</a> to test against your own production site.</p>
<h2 id="eligible-users" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#eligible-users" aria-hidden="true">#</a> What users are eligible for the origin trial?</h2>
<p>By design, origin trials are intended to <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/origin-trial-troubleshooting/#usage-restrictions">only run on a small portion of overall
Chrome traffic</a> and as
such you should always assume that even when <strong>you have enabled the origin
trial</strong> on your site, the <strong>user may not have the API active</strong>. The active
experiment group in the origin trial will start with a low proportion of users
and likely ramp up as the trial progresses. Be aware that the percentage of
Chrome users in the experiment may not match the percentage of enabled users on
your site.</p>
<p>However, to allow for unified testing across sites, that set of eligible users
should remain mostly consistent. For example, if a user is eligible for the
origin trial when they view an ad on a participating publisher site, that same
user should still be eligible when they convert on a participating advertiser
site.</p>
<p>For a user to be eligible, they must:</p>
<ul>
<li>be using <strong>Chrome 101 <a href="https://www.google.com/chrome/beta/">Beta</a> or
above</strong>.
<ul>
<li>FLEDGE requires desktop Chrome.</li>
<li>no origin trials are available on iOS versions of Chrome.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>be browsing during the <strong>active origin trial period</strong>.</li>
<li>have the <strong>Privacy Sandbox trials enabled</strong> via Settings → Security and
privacy → Privacy Sandbox, also accessible via
<code>chrome://settings/privacySandbox</code>.</li>
<li>have <strong>third-party cookies enabled</strong> via Settings → Security and privacy →
Cookies and other site data set to either &quot;Allow all cookies&quot; or &quot;Block
third-party cookies in incognito&quot;, also accessible via
<code>chrome://settings/cookies</code>.</li>
<li>be in a standard browsing session and <strong>not Incognito mode</strong>.</li>
<li>be within the <strong>active experiment group in Chrome</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="how-should-developers-feature-detect-api-support" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#how-should-developers-feature-detect-api-support" aria-hidden="true">#</a> How should developers feature detect API support?</h2>
<p>As with any web platform feature, you should detect support for the feature
before using it.</p>
<h3 id="topics" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#topics" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Topics</h3>
<p>Check for the <code>browsingTopics()</code> function in the <code>document</code>.</p>
<pre class="language-javascript"><code class="language-javascript"><span class="token keyword">if</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'browsingTopics'</span> <span class="token keyword">in</span> document<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><br>  <span class="token comment">// Topics enabled</span><br><span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre>
<h3 id="fledge" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#fledge" aria-hidden="true">#</a> FLEDGE</h3>
<p>Check for the <code>runAdAuction</code>function  in <code>navigator</code>.</p>
<pre class="language-javascript"><code class="language-javascript"><span class="token keyword">if</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'runAdAuction'</span> <span class="token keyword">in</span> navigator<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><br>  <span class="token comment">// FLEDGE enabled</span><br><span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre>
<h3 id="attribution-reporting" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#attribution-reporting" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Attribution Reporting</h3>
<p>Check for the <code>attributionReporting</code> object in the <code>window</code>.</p>
<pre class="language-javascript"><code class="language-javascript"><span class="token keyword">if</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'attributionReporting'</span> <span class="token keyword">in</span> window<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><br>  <span class="token comment">// Attribution Reporting API enabled</span><br><span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre>
<h2 id="where-can-developers-give-feedback-and-get-support" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#where-can-developers-give-feedback-and-get-support" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Where can developers give feedback and get support?</h2>
<p>The <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/feedback/">feedback overview page</a> details the
various routes for giving feedback on different aspects of the Privacy Sandbox.
There are specific sections for
<a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/feedback/#topics-api">Topics</a>,
<a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/feedback/#fledge-api">FLEDGE</a>, and <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/feedback/#measure-digital-ads">Attribution
Reporting</a> which provide
the individual links for each API.</p>
<p>We also provide regular updates on the <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/tags/progress-in-the-privacy-sandbox/">Progress in the Privacy
Sandbox</a> series which provides a summary
of important news.</p>
</content>
  </entry>
  
  
  <entry>
    <title>Deprecations and removals in Chrome 101</title>
    <link href="https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/deps-rems-101/" />
    <updated>2022-03-31T00:00:00+00:00</updated>
    <id>https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/deps-rems-101/</id>
    
    <author>
      <name>Chrome Developers</name>
    </author>
    
    <content type="html"><div class="aside aside--note">
<p>Visit ChromeStatus.com for lists of <a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/features#browsers.chrome.status%3A%22Deprecated%22">current deprecations</a> and <a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/features#browsers.chrome.status:%22Removed%22">previous removals</a>.</p>
</div>
<p>Chrome 101 beta was released on March 31, 2022 and is expected to become the
stable version in late April, 2022.</p>
<h2 id="reduce-user-agent-string-information" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#reduce-user-agent-string-information" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Reduce user agent string information</h2>
<p>Chrome is <a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/feature/5704553745874944">reducing the amount of information the User-Agent string exposes</a> in HTTP requests as well as in navigator.userAgent, navigator.appVersion, and navigator.platform. We're doing this to prevent the user agent string from being used for passive user fingerprinting. To join the origin trial, see <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/origintrials/#/view_trial/-7123568710593282047">its entry on Chrome Origin Trials</a>.</p>
<h2 id="remove-websql-in-third-party-contexts" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#remove-websql-in-third-party-contexts" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Remove WebSQL in third-party contexts</h2>
<p><a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/feature/5684870116278272">WebSQL in third-party contexts is now removed</a>. The Web SQL Database standard was first proposed in April 2009 and abandoned in November 2010. Gecko never implemented this feature and WebKit deprecated it in 2019. The W3C encourages <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/Web_Storage_API">Web Storage</a> and <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/IndexedDB_API">Indexed Database</a> for those needing alternatives.</p>
<p>Developers should expect that WebSQL itself will be deprecated and removed when usage is low enough.</p>
<h2 id="deprecation-policy" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#deprecation-policy" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Deprecation policy</h2>
<p>To keep the platform healthy, we sometimes remove APIs from the Web Platform
which have run their course. There can be many reasons why we would remove an
API, such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>They are superseded by newer APIs.</li>
<li>They are updated to reflect changes to specifications to bring alignment and
consistency with other browsers.</li>
<li>They are early experiments that never came to fruition in other browsers and
thus can increase the burden of support for web developers.</li>
</ul>
<p>Some of these changes will have an effect on a very small number of sites. To
mitigate issues ahead of time, we try to give developers advanced notice so they
can make the required changes to keep their sites running.</p>
<p>Chrome currently has a <a href="http://www.chromium.org/blink#TOC-Launch-Process:-Deprecation">process for deprecations and removals of
API's</a>,
essentially:</p>
<ul>
<li>Announce on the
<a href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/forum/#!forum/blink-dev">blink-dev</a>
mailing list.</li>
<li>Set warnings and give time scales in the Chrome DevTools Console when usage
is detected on the page.</li>
<li>Wait, monitor, and then remove the feature as usage drops.</li>
</ul>
<p>You can find a list of all deprecated features on chromestatus.com using the
<a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/features#deprecated">deprecated filter</a> and
removed features by applying the <a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/features#removed">removed
filter</a>. We will also try to
summarize some of the changes, reasoning, and migration paths in these posts.</p>
</content>
  </entry>
  
  
  <entry>
    <title>New in Chrome 100</title>
    <link href="https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/new-in-chrome-100/" />
    <updated>2022-03-29T00:00:00+00:00</updated>
    <id>https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/new-in-chrome-100/</id>
    
      
      
      <author>
        <name>Pete LePage</name>
      </author>
      
    
    <content type="html"><div class="youtube">
  <iframe class="youtube__embed" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/VK7oR5vLluk" title="youtube embed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen="" loading="lazy"></iframe>
</div>
<p>Here's what you need to know:</p>
<ul>
<li>Chrome 100 has a <a href="#chrome100">three digit version</a> number</li>
<li>Take a stroll down memory lane and celebrate
<a href="#100coolwebmoments">#100CoolWebMoments</a> since Chrome's first release.</li>
<li>There are some important changes to the <a href="#reduced-ua">user agent string</a>.</li>
<li>The <a href="#multi-screen-window-placement">Multi-Screen Window Placement API</a>
makes it possible to enumerate the displays connected to a user's machine,
and place windows on specific screens.</li>
<li>And there's plenty <a href="#more">more</a>.</li>
</ul>
<p>I'm <a href="https://petelepage.com/">Pete LePage</a>. Let's dive in and
see what's new for developers in Chrome 100.</p>
<h2 id="chrome100" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#chrome100" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Chrome 100</h2>
<p>When browsers first reached version 10, there were a few
issues as the major version number went from one digit to two. Hopefully,
we learned a few things that'll ease the transition from two digits to three.</p>
<img alt="Chrome and Firefox logo" class="float-right" decoding="async" height="420" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 800px) 800px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/oQI7f3mgM9NGOJPDnaaa.jpeg?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/oQI7f3mgM9NGOJPDnaaa.jpeg?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/oQI7f3mgM9NGOJPDnaaa.jpeg?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/oQI7f3mgM9NGOJPDnaaa.jpeg?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/oQI7f3mgM9NGOJPDnaaa.jpeg?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/oQI7f3mgM9NGOJPDnaaa.jpeg?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/oQI7f3mgM9NGOJPDnaaa.jpeg?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/oQI7f3mgM9NGOJPDnaaa.jpeg?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/oQI7f3mgM9NGOJPDnaaa.jpeg?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/oQI7f3mgM9NGOJPDnaaa.jpeg?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/oQI7f3mgM9NGOJPDnaaa.jpeg?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/oQI7f3mgM9NGOJPDnaaa.jpeg?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/oQI7f3mgM9NGOJPDnaaa.jpeg?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/oQI7f3mgM9NGOJPDnaaa.jpeg?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/oQI7f3mgM9NGOJPDnaaa.jpeg?auto=format&w=1098 1098w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/oQI7f3mgM9NGOJPDnaaa.jpeg?auto=format&w=1252 1252w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/oQI7f3mgM9NGOJPDnaaa.jpeg?auto=format&w=1428 1428w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/oQI7f3mgM9NGOJPDnaaa.jpeg?auto=format&w=1600 1600w" width="800">
<p>Chrome 100 is available now, and Firefox 100 ships very soon. These three
digit version numbers have the potential to cause issues on sites that rely
on identifying the browser version in some way. Over the last few months, the
Firefox team, and the Chrome team, ran experiments in which the browser
reported version number 100, even though it wasn't.</p>
<p>This led to a few reported issues, many of which have already been fixed. But,
we still need your help.</p>
<ul>
<li>If you are a website maintainer, test your website with Chrome and
Firefox 100.</li>
<li>If you develop a User-Agent parsing library, add tests to parse versions
greater than and equal to 100.</li>
</ul>
<p>Check out <a href="https://web.dev/chrome-firefox-100/">Chrome and Firefox soon to reach major version 100</a> on
<a href="https://web.dev/">web.dev</a> for more details.</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2 id="100coolwebmoments" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#100coolwebmoments" aria-hidden="true">#</a> 100 Cool Web Moments</h2>
<img alt="100 Cool Web Moments promo image" class="float-right" decoding="async" height="369" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 656px) 656px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/xoRkeaLxlVNuvX1DrI0F.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/xoRkeaLxlVNuvX1DrI0F.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/xoRkeaLxlVNuvX1DrI0F.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/xoRkeaLxlVNuvX1DrI0F.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/xoRkeaLxlVNuvX1DrI0F.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/xoRkeaLxlVNuvX1DrI0F.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/xoRkeaLxlVNuvX1DrI0F.png?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/xoRkeaLxlVNuvX1DrI0F.png?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/xoRkeaLxlVNuvX1DrI0F.png?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/xoRkeaLxlVNuvX1DrI0F.png?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/xoRkeaLxlVNuvX1DrI0F.png?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/xoRkeaLxlVNuvX1DrI0F.png?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/xoRkeaLxlVNuvX1DrI0F.png?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/xoRkeaLxlVNuvX1DrI0F.png?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/xoRkeaLxlVNuvX1DrI0F.png?auto=format&w=1098 1098w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/xoRkeaLxlVNuvX1DrI0F.png?auto=format&w=1252 1252w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/xoRkeaLxlVNuvX1DrI0F.png?auto=format&w=1312 1312w" width="656">
<p>It's been exciting to watch the web grow, and see all the amazing stuff you've
built over the last 100 Chrome releases. We thought it would be fun to take a
stroll down memory lane and celebrate <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/100">#100CoolWebMoments</a> that
have happened in the last 14 years.</p>
<p>Tell us which moments you loved the most. If we've missed anything (and we're
sure we have), tweet us <a href="https://twitter.com/ChromiumDev">@Chromiumdev</a> with
<a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/100CoolWebMoments">#100CoolWebMoments</a>. Enjoy!</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2 id="reduced-ua" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#reduced-ua" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Reduced User-Agent string</h2>
<p>Speaking of the user agent, Chrome 100 will be the last version to support an
unreduced User-Agent string by default. This is part of a strategy to replace
use of the User-Agent string, with the new
<a href="https://web.dev/user-agent-client-hints/">User-Agent Client Hints API</a>.</p>
<p>Starting in Chrome 101, the user agent will be gradually reduced.</p>
<p>Check out <a href="https://blog.chromium.org/2021/09/user-agent-reduction-origin-trial-and-dates.html">User Agent Reduction Origin Trial and Dates</a> on the
[Chromium blog][crblog], to learn more about what will be removed, and when.</p>
<h2 id="multi-screen-window-placement" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#multi-screen-window-placement" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Multi-screen window placement API</h2>
<p>For some apps, opening new windows and putting them in specific places, or
specific displays is an important feature. For example, when using Slides to
present, I want the slides to appear full screen on the primary display,
and my speaker notes to appear on the other display.</p>
<p>The Multi-Screen Window Placement API makes it possible to enumerate the
displays connected to the user's machine, and place windows on specific screens.</p>
<p>You can quickly check if there's more than one screen connected to the
device with <code>window.screen.isExtended</code>.</p>
<pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> isExtended <span class="token operator">=</span> window<span class="token punctuation">.</span>screen<span class="token punctuation">.</span>isExtended<span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><span class="token comment">// returns true/false</span></code></pre>
<p>But, the key functionality is in <code>window.getScreenDetails()</code>, which provides
details about the attached displays.</p>
<pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> x <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">await</span> window<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">getScreenDetails</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><span class="token comment">// returns</span><br><span class="token comment">// {</span><br><span class="token comment">//    currentScreen: {...}</span><br><span class="token comment">//    oncurrentscreenchange: null</span><br><span class="token comment">//    onscreenschange: null</span><br><span class="token comment">//    screens: [{...}, {...}]</span><br><span class="token comment">// }</span></code></pre>
<p>For example, you can determine the primary screen, then use
<code>requestFullscreen()</code> to make an element full screen on that display.</p>
<pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">try</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><br>  <span class="token keyword">const</span> screens <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">await</span> window<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">getScreenDetails</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>  <span class="token keyword">const</span> primary <span class="token operator">=</span> screens<br>         <span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">filter</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">screen</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> screen<span class="token punctuation">.</span>primary<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">0</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><br>  <span class="token keyword">await</span> elem<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">requestFullscreen</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">{</span> screen<span class="token operator">:</span> primary <span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token keyword">catch</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span>err<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><br>  console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">error</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>err<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre>
<p>And it provides a way to listen for changes, for example if a new display is plugged in or removed, the resolution changes, and so on.</p>
<pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> screens <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">await</span> window<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">getScreenDetails</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><span class="token keyword">let</span> numScreens <span class="token operator">=</span> screens<span class="token punctuation">.</span>screens<span class="token punctuation">.</span>length<span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>screens<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">addEventListener</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'screenschange'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">event</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token operator">=></span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><br>  <span class="token keyword">if</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span>screens<span class="token punctuation">.</span>screens<span class="token punctuation">.</span>length <span class="token operator">!==</span> numScreens<span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><br>    console<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">log</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'Screen count changed'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>    numScreens <span class="token operator">=</span> screens<span class="token punctuation">.</span>screens<span class="token punctuation">.</span>length<span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>  <span class="token punctuation">}</span><br><span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span></code></pre>
<p>Check out Tom's updated article
<a href="https://web.dev/multi-screen-window-placement/">Managing several displays with the Multi-Screen Window Placement API</a>
on <a href="https://web.dev/">web.dev</a> for a deeper dive.</p>
<h2 id="more" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#more" aria-hidden="true">#</a> And more!</h2>
<p>Of course there's plenty more.</p>
<p>There's a new <code>forget()</code> method for HID Devices that allow you to revoke a
permission to an HID Device that was granted by a user.</p>
<pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token comment">// Request an HID device.</span><br><span class="token keyword">const</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span>device<span class="token punctuation">]</span> <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">await</span> navigator<span class="token punctuation">.</span>hid<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">requestDevice</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>opts<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><br><br><span class="token comment">// Then later, revoke permission to the device.</span><br><span class="token keyword">await</span> device<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">forget</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span></code></pre>
<p>And for WebNFC, the <code>makeReadOnly()</code> method allows you to make NFC tags
permanently read-only.</p>
<pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> ndef <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">NDEFReader</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><span class="token keyword">await</span> ndef<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">makeReadOnly</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span></code></pre>
<h2 id="further-reading" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#further-reading" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Further reading</h2>
<p>This covers only some of the key highlights. Check the links below for
additional changes in Chrome 100.</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/new-in-devtools-100/">What's new in Chrome DevTools (100)</a></li>
<li><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/deps-rems-100/">Chrome 100 deprecations and removals</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/features#milestone%3D100">ChromeStatus.com updates for Chrome 100</a></li>
<li><a href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+log/99.0.4844.48..100.0.4896.63.48">Chromium source repository change list</a></li>
<li><a href="https://chromiumdash.appspot.com/schedule">Chrome release calendar</a></li>
</ul>
<h2 id="subscribe" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#subscribe" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Subscribe</h2>
<p>To stay up to date, <a href="https://goo.gl/6FP1a5">subscribe</a> to the
<a href="https://www.youtube.com/user/ChromeDevelopers/">Chrome Developers YouTube channel</a>,
and you'll get an email notification whenever we launch a new video.</p>
<p>I'm Pete LePage, and as soon as Chrome 101 is released, I'll be right here to
tell you what's new in Chrome!</p>
</content>
  </entry>
  
  
  <entry>
    <title>Celebrate Chrome 100 with #100CoolWebMoments</title>
    <link href="https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/100-web-moments/" />
    <updated>2022-03-29T00:00:00+00:00</updated>
    <id>https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/100-web-moments/</id>
    
      
      
      <author>
        <name>Rachel Andrew</name>
      </author>
      
    
    <content type="html"><p>Google Chrome launched in 2008, and in March 2022 we are celebrating the launch of Chrome version 100 with a scroll down memory lane. <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/100/">#100CoolWebMoments</a> remembers some cool, fun, interesting, and important things that have happened in the past 14 years.</p>
<p>A lot has happened on the web since 2008. If you read Ethan Marcotte’s 2010 A List Apart article on <a href="https://alistapart.com/article/responsive-web-design/">responsive web design</a> on the day of publication you might have done so with Chrome 4. By the time <a href="https://www.css3.info/css3-media-queries-becomes-official-w3c-recommendation-css4-media-queries-takes-shape/">Media Queries became a W3C Recommendation</a> in 2012, Chrome 19 was available.</p>
<p>Chrome was at version 43 when Alex Russell and Frances Berriman introduced <a href="https://infrequently.org/2015/06/progressive-apps-escaping-tabs-without-losing-our-soul/">Progressive Web Apps</a> in 2015, with <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2015/4/29/8511169/microsoft-edge-official-name-internet-explorer-upgrade">Microsoft announcing Edge as the new browser</a> to replace Internet Explorer in the same year.</p>
<p>In March 2017, version 57 brought us CSS Grid, the layout method was shipped in <a href="https://rachelandrew.co.uk/archives/2017/03/07/css-grid-lands-in-firefox-52/">Chrome, Firefox, and Safari</a> within days of each other. This shared release of a major feature happened again more recently, with <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/cascade-layers/">Cascade Layers</a> landing in Chrome 99, along with Firefox 97, and Safari 15.4.</p>
<p>Tell us which moments you loved the most. If we've missed anything (and we're sure we have), tweet us <a href="https://twitter.com/ChromiumDev">@ChromiumDev</a> with <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/100CoolWebMoments">#100CoolWebMoments</a>.</p>
</content>
  </entry>
  
  
  <entry>
    <title>Cookies Having Independent Partitioned State (CHIPS) origin trial</title>
    <link href="https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/chips-origin-trial/" />
    <updated>2022-03-17T00:00:00+00:00</updated>
    <id>https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/chips-origin-trial/</id>
    
      
      
      <author>
        <name>Milica Mihajlija</name>
      </author>
      
    
    <content type="html"><h2 id="what-is-chips" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#what-is-chips" aria-hidden="true">#</a> What is CHIPS?</h2>
<p><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/chips/">Cookies Having Independent Partitioned State (CHIPS)</a> is a Privacy Sandbox proposal that allows developers to opt a cookie into &quot;partitioned&quot; storage, with separate cookie jars per top-level site.</p>
<p>A partitioned third-party cookie is tied to the top-level site where it's initially set and cannot be accessed from elsewhere. The aim is to allow cookies to be set by a third-party service, but only read within the context of the top-level site where they were initially set.</p>
<h2 id="who-is-the-origin-trial-for" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#who-is-the-origin-trial-for" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Who is the origin trial for?</h2>
<p>This trial is available as a <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/third-party-origin-trials/">third-party origin trial</a>, which enables providers of embedded content to try out a new feature across multiple sites.</p>
<p>If a site enrolls in the trial as a first-party, the cookie partitioning functionality will be available to any third-party content providers on that site as well. These third-party providers should also expect to receive extra HTTP headers, indicating their enrollment in the origin trial.</p>
<h2 id="" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#" aria-hidden="true">#</a> </h2>
<h2 id="how-long-will-the-trial-run" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#how-long-will-the-trial-run" aria-hidden="true">#</a> How long will the trial run?</h2>
<p>The trial will be available from Chrome 100 to Chrome 103. Check the <a href="https://chromiumdash.appspot.com/schedule">Chrome release schedule</a> for the planned release dates.</p>
<h2 id="how-to-enroll-in-the-origin-trial" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#how-to-enroll-in-the-origin-trial" aria-hidden="true">#</a> How to enroll in the origin trial</h2>
<h3 id="prerequisites" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#prerequisites" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Prerequisites</h3>
<p>Chrome stable 100.</p>
<h3 id="steps" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#steps" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Steps</h3>
<ol>
<li>
<p>To register for the origin trial and get a token for your domains, visit the <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/origintrials/#/view_trial/1239615797433729025">CHIPS origin trial page</a>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Include the <code>Origin-Trial</code> header with a valid token in each page response:</p>
<pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">Origin<span class="token operator">-</span>Trial<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token operator">&lt;</span><span class="token constant">ORIGIN</span> <span class="token constant">TRIAL</span> <span class="token constant">TOKEN</span><span class="token operator">></span></code></pre>
</li>
<li>
<p>Include the <code>Accept-CH</code> header with the following value in each page response:</p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">Accept-CH: Sec-CH-Partitioned-Cookies</code></pre>
</li>
<li>
<p>Add <code>Partitioned</code> attribute to cookies in one of two ways:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>In <code>Set-Cookie </code>header:</p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">Set-Cookie: __Host-name=value; Secure; Path=/; SameSite=None; Partitioned;</code></pre>
</li>
<li>
<p>In Javascript:</p>
<pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js">cookieStore<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">set</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">{</span><br>name<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'__Host-name'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span><br>value<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'value'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span><br>secure<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token boolean">true</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span><br>path<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'/'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span><br>sameSite<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token string">'none'</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span><br><span class="token comment">// Set a partitioned cookie using the attribute below.</span><br>partitioned<span class="token operator">:</span> <span class="token boolean">true</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span><br><span class="token punctuation">}</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span></code></pre>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>
<h3 id="example" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#example" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Example</h3>
<p>Sites participating in the origin trial should include the following headers in their response:</p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">Origin-Trial: <ORIGIN TRIAL="" TOKEN=""><br>Accept-CH: Sec-CH-Partitioned-Cookies<br>Set-Cookie: __Host-name=value; Secure; Path=/; SameSite=None; Partitioned;</ORIGIN></code></pre>
<h2 id="verify-that-its-working" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#verify-that-its-working" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Verify that it's working</h2>
<h3 id="inspect-the-headers" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#inspect-the-headers" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Inspect the headers</h3>
<p>If you have successfully opted into the origin trial, subsequent requests from the Chrome client will include the <code>Sec-CH-Partitioned-Cookies: ?1</code> request header until the current session is ended.</p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">Sec-CH-Partitioned-Cookies: ?1<br>Cookie: __Host-name=value</code></pre>
<p>If your site receives the cookie without this client hint, opting into the origin trial was not successful and the cookie you are receiving is not partitioned.</p>
<p>If you store persistent partitioned cookies, you will receive the <code>Sec-CH-Partitioned-Cookies: ?0</code> request header for the first request to the cookies' origin.</p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">Origin-Trial: <ORIGIN TRIAL="" TOKEN=""><br>Accept-CH: Sec-CH-Partitioned-Cookies<br>Set-Cookie: __Host-name=value; Secure; Path=/; SameSite=None; Partitioned; Max-Age=86400;</ORIGIN></code></pre>
<p>If the user visits the site after the current session has ended, the first request to the site will include the following request headers:</p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">Sec-CH-Partitioned-Cookies: ?0<br>Cookie: __Host-name=value</code></pre>
<p>If you do not respond with a valid token in the <code>Origin-Trial</code> header and <code>Accept-CH: Sec-CH-Partitioned-Cookies</code>, then the partitioned cookies on the machine will be converted to unpartitioned cookies.</p>
<p>For more details, check out <a href="https://www.chromium.org/updates/chips/">CHIPS documentation on chromium.org</a>.</p>
<h3 id="devtools" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#devtools" aria-hidden="true">#</a> DevTools</h3>
<ol>
<li>Go to <code>chrome://flags/#partitioned-cookies</code> and change the setting to &quot;Enabled&quot;.</li>
<li>Restart Chromium by clicking the &quot;Relaunch&quot; button in the bottom-right corner, or by navigating to chrome://restart.</li>
<li>Go to <code>chrome://settings/cookies</code> and make sure that the radio button is set to &quot;Allow all cookies&quot; or &quot;Block third-party cookies in Incognito&quot;.</li>
<li>Load the site with the embed.</li>
<li>Open Open DevTools to <strong>Application</strong> &gt; <strong>Cookies</strong> &gt; yourSite and look for the <strong>Partition Key</strong> column in DevTools.</li>
</ol>
<div class="aside aside--note">
<p>Not every client will have the origin trial enabled.</p>
</div>
<h2 id="additional-details" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#additional-details" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Additional details</h2>
<h3 id="cookies-requirements" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#cookies-requirements" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Cookies requirements</h3>
<ul>
<li>Partitioned cookies must be set with the <code>Secure</code> and <code>Path=/</code> and without the <code>Domain</code> attribute.</li>
<li><code>SameParty</code> attribute cannot be used along with <code>Partitioned.</code></li>
</ul>
<p>Chrome will enforce these rules for cookies set with the <code>Partitioned</code> attribute whether cookie partitioning is enabled or disabled. Cookies that are set incorrectly will be rejected.</p>
<p>If cookie partitioning is disabled, but the cookie is set with the correct attributes, Chrome will ignore the  <code>Partitioned</code> attribute and the resulting cookie will still be sent in requests to its host on different top-level sites than where it was set.</p>
<p>Partitioned cookies should include <code>SameSite=None</code> attribute as well, to allow cookies to be sent in a third-party context in browsers that do not support cookie partitioning.</p>
<h3 id="javascript-and-service-workers" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#javascript-and-service-workers" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Javascript and service workers</h3>
<p>Frames that opt into the origin trial will have access to reading and writing partitioned cookies via JavaScript APIs such as <code>document.cookie</code> and the CookieStore API. Frames that are not in the trial's scripts will not be able to read nor write partitioned cookies.<br>
The CHIPS origin trial is currently not supported in service workers.</p>
<h2 id="engage-and-share-feedback" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#engage-and-share-feedback" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Engage and share feedback</h2>
<ul>
<li>Raise issues and follow the discussion on <a href="https://github.com/WICG/CHIPS/issues">GitHub</a>.</li>
<li>Ask questions and join discussions on the <a href="https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/privacy-sandbox-dev-support">Privacy Sandbox Developer Support repo</a>.</li>
<li>Explore different avenues for giving <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/feedback/">feedback on Privacy Sandbox proposals</a>.</li>
</ul>
